stem: The triage nurse in a Women's Health center is assessing four clients in their third trimester. Based on the data in the Obstetrical Assessment Log, categorize each finding as a normal discomfort of pregnancy or a danger sign requiring immediate intervention.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 32-week G1P0. Reports a 'dull, throbbing headache' and blurry vision.
Patient B: 34-week G2P1. Reports lower back pain and feeling 'heavy' in the pelvis at night.
Patient C: 36-week G1P0. Reports her ankles are swollen after being on her feet all day.
Patient D: 38-week G3P2. Reports sudden, rapid weight gain (4 lbs in 3 days) and facial swelling.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: Baseline BPs for A and D were 110/70 and 115/75 respectively.

rows.text: Continuous frontal headache with visual disturbances
Dependent ankle edema at the end of the day
Lower back pain relieved by rest
Generalized edema of the face and hands
Rapid weight gain (> 2 lbs per week)

rationale.correct: Danger signs (c2) include neurovascular signs (headache/vision changes), generalized edema (face/hands), and rapid weight gain which indicate fluid retention from potential complications. Normal discomforts (c1) include dependent edema (ankles/gravity-related) and musculoskeletal back pain. The Obstetrical Log for A and D confirms high BP and proteinuria, validating their 'Danger' status.
clinicalPearls: 4+ Reflexes (Clonus) indicates CNS irritability and high seizure risk (Eclampsia).
Always ask about epigastric pain; it can signify liver swelling in HELLP syndrome.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that ankle edema is always a danger sign.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the edema is only in the lower extremities and goes away with elevation, it is 'Dependent' and usually normal.

mnemonic.title: HEAD
mnemonic.expansion: H-Headache, E-Edema (Facial), A-Abdominal Pain (RUQ), D-Dazzling eyes (Vision).
